item.title: We (rOpenSci) wond 3rd place in the PLoS-Mendeley Binary Battle!
item.description:
We entered two of our packages for integrating with PLoS Journals (rplos) and Mendeley (RMendeley) in the Mendeley-PLoS Binary Battle.  Get them at GitHub (rplos, RMendeley).

We won third place!!  This gives us a $1,000 prize, plus a Parrot AR Drone helicopter.

item.title: R meetings topics
item.description:
Potential topics for our R class at Rice:

  1. Ordinations (incl. rarefactions, etc.)
  2. Phylogenetics (incl. complete workflow from searching GenBank to phylogenetic tree output)
  3. Simulations (for loops, functions, etc.)
  4. Advanced visualizations (ggplot2, lattice, googleVis, etc.)
  5. Blitz day: a series of small talks given by class members
  6. Web data acquisition (introduce rOpenSci, and include calling external programs from R, e.g., phylometa or MrBayes)

item.title: Friday; simulations on phylogeny outgroup influence on phylogenetic meta-analysis model fit
item.description:
Note to self: not sure if I did the simulation right....

Modeling: wanted to find out how an outgroup on a long branch (e.g., two species of plants are in a phylogeny where the remaining species are all animals) would influence model fit in phylogenetic meta-analysis. So I did like so:

Simulation details:

**Simulated 100 trees under each of the two following conditions:

-regular trees, randomly generated coalescent tree (in fig legend as "reg")
-outgroup added trees, randomly generated coalescent tree with two fewer species than a reg tree, then an outgroup of two species added on a long branch (in fig legend as "out")
Each of the above two cases were generated at 10, 20, 40, 60, 80, and 100 species. 
I also evolved a trait on each tree (here, we assume this trait is the effect size), and created a dataset for each tree (with the effect size, variance set to 1 for each species, and no grouping variable).  This is perhaps not ideal...
I then ran all these trees and datasets through Phylometa (from R of course), and plotted the AIC max lik model fit (left two panels) and the ratio of phy:trad max lik model fit (right two panels), for both fixed (top two panels) and random (bottom two panels) effects models. 
The line fits are Loess, so no particular model was fitted there, just to help see the patterns. 

Here is the output from the simulation:

Bottom line: It seems that indeed, an outroup on a long branch does make model fit worse.

item.title: Wednesday
